reviewText: Gotta admit, Daniel Henney is a sexy, good looking, romantic leading man.  No wonder Koran women adore him, and he's an American born from the Midwest.  Hot shot NY lawyer Sam Chao is sent to Shanghai to make a contract deal.  His seniors at the law firm are pressing the race card, but Sam is an American.  This is made so obvious when he meets the relocation specialist, a no-nonsense ex-pat Eliza Coupe, who's far more Chinese than Sam.  Rough start on the job, foreign city, even his apartment, but Sam starts to groove and find romance.  Sweet, lightweight, romance comedy with befuddled hero getting rescued.  Nice turns on American expats as new immigrants overseas, what Sam and a little girl share as being outsiders trying to fit in, and finding happiness in unexpected ways.  A good date movie.  Good lessons on Mandarin Chinese from Eliza Coupe.  Ni xiang chi  shenmo - What would you like to eat?
Title: N/A

reviewText: While this movie can be predictable at times, it is a fresh look at a modern China and the influx of foreigners into this changing society. It held my interest completely, and may hold some lessons about business in China.
Title: N/A

reviewText: SHANGHAI CALLING (Writ./Dir. Daniel Hsia, 2012, 100 minutes) is one of those movies that causes me to ache with anger and resentment at the fact that we miss these gems in the first place. I cannot understand the wasted hard work, the talent, that essentially goes down the drain from lack of an audience for such films.This jewel of a film, which should be seen by everyone, grossed just over $10,000 when it opened. That's right, this classic film grossed less than it costs to buy a crappy SUV.Oscar-worthy all around, this is the story of gorgeous corporate lawyer Sam Chou (Daniel Henney), a Chinese-American who is tapped to go to Shanghai by his firm. Since he is of Chinese descent - though 100% American - his firm thinks he'll be more effective. The odious task on which he embarks will not only warm your heart, it will open your eyes about Sino-American business practices.Arriving in Shanghai, Sam quickly learns that the American "expat" community understands what it really is: a group of immigrants. The "mayor" of the community is a charming and understated Bill Paxton; along the way, others will appear and make this film totally worthwhile and fun.I must say, not only Daniel Henney but this entire film was redolent of a fine Buster Keaton film. Being an aficionado and connoisseur, I felt the entire time as if BK had made this film. Henney has a Keatonesque talent for the smooth, elegant bumbling that endears an audience immediately. Since this is a true family comedy, there is no need for Henney's character to be a true shark. As a comic-dramatic actor, Henney is set free here in a way only Keaton understood/exploited properly.And let's face one fact: Henney is not tough on the old eyeballs in the least. He is one of the sexiest men ever. My favorite scene, one I urge you to watch for, is the café scene in which Sam meets a mysterious, wise stranger. That was so funny I found it hard to breathe. And let me add that the Chinese techno-pop music in the soundtrack is incredibly upbeat and relevant - but it's fun, and I'd like to own the soundtrack along with the film.With the amazing talents of Eliza Coupe, Alan Ruck, Geng Le, Zhu Zhu, Jim Bennett, and Arran Hawkins.
summary: "It's time to get in touch with your culture ... by having sex with it!"

reviewText: Want to spend a pleasant couple of hours in Shanghai? Shanghai Calling can take you there for a few hundred dollars less than airfare.

reviewerName: Michael B. Druxman "A Good Story is a Terribl...
reviewText: SHANGHAI CALLING is an entertaining "fish-out-of-water" romantic comedy, an American-Chinese co-production.Daniel Henney plays a hotshot young Chinese-American attorney, born and bred in New York City.  Hoping to make partner after winning a major case for his law firm, he is, instead, sent to Shanghai where he doesn't speak the language, nor is he comfortable with the culture.  It also appears that he is about to blow a billion dollar deal for a major client of his firm.Written and directed by Daniel Hsia, SHANGHAI CALLING has a likeable cast, which includes Eliza Coupe, Alan Ruck and Bill Paxton, as well as several amusing sequences.  However, watching the film, I couldn't help thinking that it could have been much better had it not been a Chinese-American co-production.Before I create an international incident, I should explain.First, much of the dialogue in the movie is in Chinese, which is okay, but the subtitles are so small and flash by so fast on the bottom of the screen that it is difficult to read them, let alone watch what is happening on screen.  For example, what could have been a laugh-out-loud visual comedy sequence is totally squandered because one is trying to read the subtitles.Second, screenwriter Hsia, at times, seems to forget that this is a story about Henney and his misadventures in Shanghai.  Yes, it is nice to build up the roles of the secondary characters, particularly those portrayed by Chinese actors, but those scenes distract from and impede the primary plotline.  Hsia does not protect the "spine" of his story and, in failing to do so, the ultimate conversion of Henney from a ruthless lawyer to a man with a conscience is not as convincing as it should be.I am all for giving actors, whatever their nationality, more scenes, but not at the expense of good storytelling.Still, SHANGHAI CALLING is an enjoyable way to pass two hours.The DVD from Anchor Bay Entertainment contains a "Behind the Scenes" featurette. Michael B. Druxman
summary: An Enjoyable Way to Pass Two Hours
